titleStmt.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of ductile NbTaTiV refractory high entropy alloy prepared by powder metallurgy

analytic.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of ductile NbTaTiV refractory high entropy alloy prepared by powder metallurgy

biblStruct.note: Received Date: 17 August 2018 Revised Date: 16 October 2018 Accepted Date: 18 October 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) are promising high-temperature structural materials due to their high melting point and extraordinarily high yield strength. However, their industrial application is greatly restricted due to their limited room-temperature ductility. In the present investigation, a ductile and strong single-phase NbTaTiV RHEA was synthesized by powder metallurgy method. Effects of the sintering temperature on the phase formation, microstructural evolution and the mechanical properties of the NbTaTiV RHEA were characterized. The results show that the NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at 1700 o C has an equiaxed single bcc phase microstructure, no obvious porosity and compositional segregation can be observed.

The alloy exhibits a relatively high hardness of 510 HV, yield strength of 1.37 GPa, and compressive fracture strength of 2.19 GPa with a high fracture strain of 23 % at room temperature. Typical strain softening and steady state flow occur during compressive deformation at high temperatures. During deformation at 1000 o C, the alloy still exhibits high yield strength of 437 MPa with a compression strain over than 40 %. The outstanding mechanical properties is mainly attributed to the homogeneous and fine microstructures, and solid solution strengthening effect. It can be concluded that the powder metallurgy is a promising way for preparing ductile RHEAs with outstanding comprehensive mechanical properties.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The continuing development of advanced gas turbine aeroengines requires structural materials capable of withstanding increasing operating temperatures and mechanical loads. Nowadays, the maximum turbine inlet temperature in practice in advanced turbines has been rising up to 1600 o C [1], which exceeds the melting points of most of the traditional Ni-based superalloys [2]. The limited service temperatures of Ni-based superalloys make the further improvement of turbine efficiency to be extremely difficult. Therefore, the development of excellent high-temperature structural materials is imminent, and it is expected to be an alternative material for Ni-based superalloys at higher temperatures.

A recently proposed concept of high-entropy alloys (HEAs), consisting more than four principal metallic elements, have received wide attention due to their unique structures and excellent mechanical properties. It is reported that these alloys have very high entropy of mixing, which makes HEA has a high tendency to form solid solutions instead of intermetallic compounds [3]. Furthermore, these reported outstanding physical and mechanical properties also is claimed to be attributed to the four core effects of HEAs, including high configurational entropy, sluggish diffusion, severe lattice distortion, and cock-tail effects. Based on the design concept of high entropy alloys, by selecting refractory alloy elements (including group IV (Ti, Zr, Hf), V(V, Nb, Ta), and VI (Cr, Mo, W)) as the components, these developed refractory HEAs (RHEAs) generally possess high melting temperature, outstanding room-temperature and high temperature mechanical properties, excellent thermal stability, which opens up the possibilities in the alloy developments satisfying the above demands [4].

Numerous recent researches about the RHEAs are originated from the MoNbTaW and MoNbTaVW HEAs proposed by O.N. Senkov et al. at 2010 [5,6]. It is reported that the BCC MoNbTaW and MoNbTaVW HEAs maintained yield strengths of 405 and 477 MPa at 1600 o C respectively, which is noticeably higher than that of Inconel 718 and Haynes 230 [6]. Furthermore, Yu Zou et al. [7] reported that the MoNbTaW thin films also showed substantially enhanced thermal stability for high temperature, long-durations conditions (at 1100 o C for 3 days). Unfortunately, these RHEAs are generally exhibit high density and brittle at room temperature, fail by cracking at low

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: 3 compressive strains and suffer from limited formability. These shortcomings have become the current bottleneck for industrial applications of RHEAs as structural materials. In order to enhance their ductility and reduce their strikingly high density, Saad Sheikh et al. [8] reported that decreasing the average valence electron numbers, or valence electron concentrations, was effective in ductilizing refractory alloys. As reported, group VI (Cr, Mo and W) refractory metals exhibited well-known room temperature embrittlement [9,10], while alloying the group VI or V (V, Nb, Ta) transition metals with group IV (Ti, Zr, Hf) metals can transform these RHEAs into intrinsically ductile materials. Therefore, a series of BCC HEAs have been designed with the additions of lighter elements, such as Ti and Zr, yielding compositions such as HfNbTaTiZr [8], NbTaTiV [11], HfMoNbTiZr [12], NbTaTiVW [11] and MoNbTaV [13], etc. One exception is the TaNbTiV alloy, which has a high melting temperature of 2275 o C [14] and a plasticity of over 50% at room temperature [11].
However, the yield strength of NbTaTiV is only 965 MPa at room temperature and its high temperature strength is insufficient [11].

It is well known that the strength of a material is not only significantly influenced by their chemical composition, but also inseparable from their microstructure. As reported in the literatures, most of the reported HEAs are prepared by the casting route [3,4]. These as-casted RHEAs generally exhibit coarse dendritic structures. In addition, component segregation is also difficult to avoid in these as-cast alloys.

These intrinsic processing problems are great harm to the mechanical properties of HEAs. In order to solve these problems, resent works [15][16][17] showed that HEA can be prepared by powder metallurgy (P/M) technology, including mechanical alloying (MA) and subsequent consolidation process, such as spark plasma sintering (SPS), and hot pressing. During the spark plasma sintering (SPS) process, powders can be melted and consolidation in few minutes to tens of minutes. Therefore, the grain growth can be significantly suppressed. In the previous research [15], we prepared CoCrFeNi HEA by the P/M process. The alloy exhibited a high yield strength of 359 MPa and ultimate strength of 712.5 MPa, which was almost 117% and 78% higher than that of the as-cast alloy, without causing any embrittlement. The P/M process is proved to be an effective approach for the synthesis of materials with uniform fine microstructures and superior compositional homogeneity.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

div.p: In this study, NbTaTiV RHEA is prepared by powder metallurgy (P/M) with an aim to improve its strength, while retaining reasonable toughness at room temperature.
Effects of the sintering temperature on the microstructural evolution and the mechanical properties of NbTaTiV RHEA are investigated. The strengthening mechanisms of the P/M alloys are discussed.

div.head: Experimental procedures
div.p: High purity (>99.5 wt.%) Nb, Ta, Ti and V powders were used in this study. The powders in equiatomic composition (Nb:Ta:Ti:V=1:1:1:1) was ball milled in a tungsten carbide vial with argon atmosphere for 12 h. The ball-to-powder mass ratio was 10:1 and milling speed was 250 rpm. After milling, the mixed NbTaTiV powders were consolidated through spark plasma sintering (SPS) ( FCT HP D 25/3, German).

The sintering temperatures were 1500, 1600, and 1700 °C, respectively. The holding time was 30 minutes and the pressure was 30 MPa. Finally, the sample was cooled by a circulating water cooling device.

Cylindrical specimens (φ6×9 mm) were cut from the as-sintered NbTaTiV RHEA for the compression tests. An Instron-3369 and Gleeble-3180 devices were employed to accomplish the room temperature and high temperature compressive tests respectively. The strain rate was 10 -3 s -1 at all cases. The representative data for each condition were obtained by averaging three values of the test results. Room temperature compression tests were performed until the fracture of the specimen.

High temperature compression tests were carried out at 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C, and 1000 °C, respectively. Before the high temperature compression tests, these specimens were heated to the set temperature at 10 °C/s and then held for 5 min. High temperature compressive tests were performed to a compressive engineering strain of 40 %.
Particle size distribution of the raw powders and as-mixed powders was characterized by a laser particle size analyzer (MICRO-PLUS, MALVERN).

Interstitial impurities (C, H, and O elements) in the raw powders and mixed powders were determined using a LECO TCH 600 analyzer. The microstructure of these specimens were characterized by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JSM-6360LV, Japan), equipped with the energy dispersive spectrometer The element distribution of these alloys was investigated with electron probe microanalysis (EPMA, EPMA-1600, JEOL, Japan). Microhardness was measured by a Vickers microhardness tester (MicroMet5104, Buehler, Lake Bluff, IL, USA) with an indenter load of 0.2 kg.

div.head: Characterization of the powders
div.p: Figure 1 shows the morphology of the raw elemental and mixed NbTaTiV powders.

The average particle size and the content of the interstitial impurities (C, H, and O elements) of the Ta, Nb, V and Ti raw powders and the mixed powder were listed in Table 1. It is found that all the raw elemental powders are in irregular shape with particle size less than 45 µm. After milling, the particle size is slightly decreased, and the concentration of O element is slightly increased, indicating a slightly oxidation of the raw powders. As shown in Table 1, it also demonstrates that a significant increase of C and O content could be detected in the as-sintered alloy, which is potentially ascribed to the oxidation of metals and the diffusion of C from the flexible graphite foil during the sintering process.

div.head: Phase identification
div.p: Figure 2 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the NbTaTiV HEA after sintered at 1500 o C, 1600 o C, and 1700 o C respectively. It is clearly that only BCC solid solution phase can be detected in all these alloys. These identified diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns agrees well with the crystal-plane indices of BCC structure, indicating that the NbTaTiV HEA exhibits a single phase structure. As the sintering temperature increased from 1500 o C to 1700 o C, there is no deviation from the diffraction peaks except the increasing relatively diffraction intensity. According to the rule of mixtures (i.e. Vegard's law [18]), the theoretical crystal lattice parameter a mix of the disordered BCC solid solutions in equiatomic NbTaTiV RHEA is calculated to be a mix =322.98 pm. Whereas the lattice parameters determined by the XRD is 323 pm based on the
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT6
div.p: Debye-Scherrer equation [19]. It can be concluded that the calculated value for the pure single-phase NbTaTiV RHEA is very close to the experimental result. respectively. It is apparent that these NbTaTiV RHEAs are basically composed with three distinct distinguishable areas, i.e. a "brighter" white area, gray matrix and black region. The white region is distinctly enriched in Ta. This qualitatively implies that the white area may be enriched in elements with more electrons. Simultaneously, significantly compositional segregation of V, Ti, and Nb in the gray matrix is also detected, indicating an incomplete alloying process. Small fraction of the black points can be detected as the pores which formed during the sintering process. On the contrary, as the sintering temperature increased to 1700 o C (Fig. 4), it is found that the white area is disappeared. No obvious compositional segregation is detected, indicating a fairly homogeneous microstructure. These pores are also disappeared, indicating a high relative density (over 99.5 %) of the sintered alloy. The NbTaTiV RHEA, which was sintered at 1700 o C, exhibits the highest microhardness of 510.9 HV, much higher than 298 HV for the as-casted alloy [11]. Both the yield strength and the fracture strength of NbTaTiV RHEA are obviously higher than the as-casted alloy [11]. Under all conditions, the NbTaTiV RHEA exhibits more than 20 % compression plasticity before fracture and a large work-hardening capacity. As compared to the as-casted alloy [11], the high strength and reasonable ductility of the P/M alloy can be attributed to the refined and homogeneous microstructure, as well as the elimination of pores caused by the high sintering temperature. Table 2 summarizes the compressive properties of the traditional as-cast RHEAs, P/M RHEAs and the present P/M NbTaTiV RHEA.

div.head: Microstructures of the NbTaTiV RHEA
div.p: Although the traditional as-cast RHEAs, such as the MoNbTaW [6], MoNbTaVW [6],

NbTaVW [11], MoNbTaV [13], HfMoTaTiZr [20], HfMoNbTiZr [12], generally exhibited a superior yield strength than that of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA, their poor ductility at room temperature limits its processing performance. On the contrary, the intrinsically ductile as-cast RHEAs, such as the HfNbTaTiZr [21], NbTaTiV [11],

AlNbTaTiV [14], were reported to have outstanding compression plasticity, however, their compressive strength were insufficient and need to be improved. Compared with the P/M RHEAs, such as NbTa0.5TiZrAl0.2 [22] and NbMoTaVW [23], the compressive strength of the NbTaTiV RHEA is not high, however, its ductility is apparently much better. Therefore, it can be concluded that the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA exhibits an excellent comprehensive mechanical properties with superior yield strength than that of the ductile RHEAs as well as much more outstanding compression plasticity than that of the traditional brittle RHEAs. patterns. There is a clear passivation at the edge of the cleavage plane, therefore these alloy have a certain degree of plasticity. Previous study [25] claimed that the ductility of the as-cast alloy was generally restricted by the stress concentration at the interface regions between soft dendrite and hard interdendrite. The relatively homogeneous microstructure in the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA may result in the low concentration difference, low stress concentration, and thus the enhanced overall ductility. HfMo0.5NbSi0.3TiV0.5 [28], etc. Although the typical RHEAs, such as MoNbTaW and MoNbTaVW [6], were reported to exhibited superior high temperature strength than that of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA in the present study, their ductility at room temperature or high temperatures were reported to be significantly restricted. Of particular note is P/M NbTaTiV RHEA, which did not fracture at the test compressive strain limit of 40%, indicating outstanding high temperature ductility.

div.head: Phase formation
div.p: As reported, predicting the phase composition of high-entropy alloys is a very challenging task. In this part, several empirical criteria are summarized to predict structure stability and phase formation in NbTaTiV RHEA. The parameters include enthalpy of mixing ( mix H ∆ ) [24], entropy of mixing ( mix S ∆ ) [24], melting points ( mix m T ) [24], atomic size difference (δ ) [24], Ω parameter [30], valence electron concentration (VEC) [31], pauling electronegativity difference ( χ ∆ ) [32] are summarized in Table 4. The details on the calculation of these criteria can be found in

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: 9 the related literatures. As suggested by these criteria, it is reported that a high value of mix S ∆ is regarded to be important in stabilizing the solid solution phases, as the Gibbs free energy is reduced by the entropy term ( mix T S ∆ ). Zhang et al. [33] suggested that the criteria for forming random solid solutions alloys solidified from the melt were -15 kJ/mol < mix H ∆ <5 kJ/mol and δ<6.6 %. Furthermore, it was reported that a small δ is desirable for large mutual solubility [34] and the solid-solution HEAs are located at Ω ≥1.1 and δ ≤6.6 % [30]. In addition, a low value of χ ∆ will favor solid solution phase formation [32]. Guo et al. [31] reported that BCC phase is stable at low VEC(<6.87). Based on these empirical criteria, each of the calculated values for the current alloy is presented in Table 4. It can be concluded that all these calculated values favor formation of single-phase solid solution with BCC structure and this agrees with the experimental observations based on the XRD analysis results.
Therefore, a BCC structure is expected to be stable in the NbTaTiV RHEA.

div.head: Mechanical properties of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA
div.p: As shown in Fig. 7 and Table 2, the microhardness and compressive yield strength of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA at room temperature are significantly increased by approximately 71 % and 42 % than that of the as-cast alloy respectively. However, it is unfortunately that the compression plasticity of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA is limited to be approximately 20 %. Although such a tradeoff relationship between the strength and plasticity is conventional, we insist on the preparation of high strength HEAs with reasonable ductility with the aim to ensure their processability and thus broaden their application field.

It is well-known that mechanical properties of materials are basically influenced by several strengthening mechanisms, including solid solution strengthening, grain boundary strengthening, strain strengthening, dislocations strengthening and precipitate strengthening, etc. Based on ROM guidelines as reported [13,24], the yield strength and microhardness of the equiatomic NbTaTiV RHEA can be roughly calculated to be 272.5 MPa and 947.75 MPa, respectively. Table 5 presents the atomic radii, shear moduli, microhardness and yield strength (σ 0.2 ) of the pure elements. It is apparent that the calculated values are much lower than the measured values of the as-cast [11] or the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA (Table 5). The results suggest that the solid In the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA with single BCC structure, each atom can be considered as a solute atom. Based on the classical Labush approach [36], the SSS effect in NbTaTiV RHEA also can be reckoned simply as follows.
At first, the SSS effect in the NbTaTiV RHEA caused by each of the components (i-th) can be expressed as:

Finally, the calculated yield strength of the NbTaTiV RHEA can be roughly estimated as following equation. 7. According to the ROM rules, the shear modulus of the NbTaTiV RHEA is estimated to be 52.025 GPa.
The calculated yield strength of the equiatomic NbTaTiV RHEA using Eq. ( 6) is equal to 977.5 MPa, which agrees well with experimental results for the as-cast
NbTaTiV RHEA reported in the literature [11]. The hardness of metals and alloys is generally nearly triple their yield strength [37], so the hardness can be estimated using:
while the calculated hardness of the NbTaTiV RHEA is 2932.5 MPa using Eq. ( 7), which is also very closed to the experimental results for the as-cast NbTaTiV RHEA [11].

Considering the same SSS effect in the P/M and as-cast NbTaTiV RHEA, however, it is apparent that the room-temperature yield strength of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA, which was sintered at 1700 o C, still has 408 MPa higher than the as-cast alloy. It suggests that the aforementioned semi-empirical model is subjected to a number of uncertain factors. It indicates that other strengthening mechanisms have also played a very significant role. As reported, the as-cast NbTaTiV RHEA exhibited a typical dendritic microstructure [11]. The grain sizes for these alloys are 100-200 µm in extent with secondary dendrite arm spacing in the range of 10-30 µm. Note that the grain size of the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA in the present study is approximately 20-40 µm, the significant enhanced yield strength may be partially attributed to the grain boundary strengthening. However, as discussed in the previous research, we also evaluated the the yield strength increase caused by grain size refinement in the as-extruded CoCrFeNi HEA [15]. Considering that the grain size of the P/M CoCrFeNi HEA was 35 µm，which is much smaller than 290 µm for the as-casted alloy, the strength enhancement caused by grain boundary strengthening was calculated to be just only 24.9 MPa. In the light of the small change in grain size between the as-casted NbTaTiV RHEA and P/M one, this value can be reasonably suggested to be relatively negligible, suggesting that grain boundary strengthening is not the dominant mechanism.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 12
div.p: In addition, the SSS effect caused by the interstitial atoms also can be considered as another important influence factor for the enhanced mechanical properties of P/M NbTaTiV RHEA. As showed in Table 1, the content of C and O in the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at 1700 o C is measured to be as high as 0.19 wt. % and 0.48 wt. % respectively. The previously reported data on CoCrFeNiMn-0.5C and Fe40.4Ni11.3Mn34.8Al7.5Cr6-1.1C high entropy alloys indicates that interstitial element C has a strong solid solution strengthening effect [38,39]. The yield strength increases by 120 MPa/at.% C in the CoCrFeNiMn-0.5C alloy, while the increase of yield strength is 178 MPa/at.%C in the Fe40.4Ni11.3Mn34.8Al7.5Cr6-1.1C. In addition, it was found in our previous work that interstitial element O (~720 ppm) in
CoCrFeNi HEA also caused a significant increase of yield strength (>100 MPa) [15].
In this study, the oxygen content (0.48 wt. %) is much higher than that in Ref. [15].
Therefore, solid solution strengthening caused by the interstitial atoms (C and O) can also be an important strengthening mechanism for the P/M NbTaTiV RHEA.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: NbTaTiV RHEA was synthesized through P/M method. The effects of the sintering temperature on the phase formation, microstructural evolution and the mechanical properties of the NbTaTiV alloys were characterized, the following conclusions are drawn:

(1) Fine and homogeneous microstructure can be obtained in the NbTaTiV RHEA through P/M method. The average grain sizes of these NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at The P/M NbTaTiV RHEA showed a combined high yield strength of 1.37 GPa and reasonable ductility over 20 % at room temperature.

div.head: Tables and table captions:
div.p: The P/M NbTaTiV RHEA still exhibited high yield strength of 437 MPa at 1000 o C with a compressive strain over than 40 %.
The improvement of the compressive strength was caused by the solid solution strengthening and fine-grained strengthening.

figure.figDesc: Figure 3 and 4 demonstrate the SEM image and the EMPA mappings of the alloying components in the NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at 1500 o C and 1700 o C

figure.head: Figure 5
figure.figDesc: Figure 5 shows the EBSD results of the as-sintered NbTaTiV RHEA. The average grain size of these NbTaTiV RHEAs sintered at 1500 o C, 1600 o C and 1700 o C is approximately 24 µm, 30 µm and 38 µm respectively. As the sintering temperature increased, the grain size distribution is more uniform and the average grain growth of the as-sintered alloys is neglectable. H.W. Yao et al. [11] investigated the microstructure and compressive properties of the NbTaTiV RHEA synthesized by vacuum arc melting in a Ti-gettered, high-purity argon atmosphere. The as-cast NbTaTiV RHEA exhibited a coarse dendritic microstructure with the severe component segregation.

Fig. 6. It is clearly that the microhardness of the as-sintered NbTaTiV RHEA is gradually increased with the increasing sintering temperature. Based on the microstructure characterization above, the improved microhardness of the as-sintered

figure.head: Figure 7
figure.figDesc: Figure 7 shows the engineering stress-strain curves for the NbTaTiV RHEA at room temperature. All alloys exhibit high yield compressive strength and good plasticity. The yield strength of NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at 1500 o C, 1600 o C and 1700 o C are 1108 MPa, 1308 MPa, and 1373 MPa, respectively, while their maximum compressive fracture strength are 1821 MPa, 2073 MPa, and 2189 MPa, respectively.

figure.head: Figure 8
figure.figDesc: Figure 8 illustrates the room temperature fracture morphologies of the P/MNbTaTiV RHEA sintered at different temperatures. The dimple rupture mode can be seen in Fig.8ais consistency with its moderate ductility. It is apparent that all the

figure.head: Figure 9
figure.figDesc: Figure 9 demonstrates the high temperature compressive engineering stress-strain curves for the NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at 1700 o C. Typical compression mechanical properties at high temperatures are summarized in Table 3. Samples deformed at 700 o C and 800 o C show continuous strengthening at the initial strain range up to 15 %, and then their strength continuously decreased. Further increases in temperature to 900 o C and 1000 o C led to a rapid decline in yield stress and apparent softening. As the compression temperature increased to 1000 o C, the NbTaTiV RHEA sintered at 1700 o C still retains high yield strength of 437 MPa, which is much higher than that of typical ductile RHEAs, such as HfNbTaTiZr [26], NbTiVZr[27],
SSS) may play a more important role in the NbTaTiV RHEA than the simple ROM rule[35].
